paper.title: A programmable two-qubit quantum processor in silicon

comparisons.description: Bell state fidelity from 3-axis tomography (ZZ, XX, YY correlators)

emulator.failure_description: Emulator returns perfect fidelity (F=1.000) for all 4 Bell states, confirming circuit correctness.

tuna9.failure_description: Tuna-9 mean Bell fidelity 0.829 (range 0.808-0.842), slightly below Watson's 0.85-0.89. Expected: Watson's 2-qubit chip was purpose-built for this experiment; Tuna-9 uses 2 of 9 qubits on a general-purpose processor. The 2-qubit gate (CZ via tunable coupler) adds more decoherence than Watson's exchange-based CNOT.

comparisons.description: 1-bit Deutsch-Josza algorithm correctly classifies all 4 oracles

emulator.failure_description: 4/4 oracles classified correctly with P(success)=1.000 on emulator.

tuna9.failure_description: 4/4 oracles classified correctly. Constant oracles: P(qa=0)=99.3-99.6%. Balanced oracles: P(qa=1)=87.1-87.3%. Mean success probability 93.3%.

comparisons.description: 2-qubit Grover search finds correct target for all 4 possible marked items

emulator.failure_description: Emulator achieves P(target)=1.000 for all 4 targets, confirming ideal circuit behavior.

tuna9.failure_description: Tuna-9 EXCEEDS Watson's published results. Mean P(target)=89.2% vs Watson's ~80%. Superconducting transmons with tunable couplers achieve higher gate fidelity for the 5-CNOT Grover circuit than Si/SiGe exchange-based gates. All 4 targets correctly identified.

summary.key_finding: Cross-platform replication of Watson's 2-qubit silicon experiments on superconducting hardware. Tuna-9 exceeds Watson's Grover success rate (89.2% vs ~80%) thanks to higher 2-qubit gate fidelity for multi-gate circuits. Bell fidelities slightly lower (0.829 vs 0.87) likely due to Tuna-9's longer gate times and spectator qubit decoherence on the 9-qubit chip. All algorithmic experiments (DJ, Grover) replicate successfully.

backend_comparison.interpretation: Superconducting transmons excel at multi-gate circuits (Grover: 5 CNOTs) where cumulative gate error matters. Silicon spin qubits show better entanglement fidelity for single CNOT circuits (Bell states) due to their lower crosstalk in a 2-qubit-only processor.
